可圈可点的游戏。完了1多多小时游戏体验一般，主要是感觉节奏过慢，玩法单一。总结如下：
[list]
    [*]游戏画面还是非常不错的，除了人物动作和表情有点僵硬，场景画面渲染氛围很到位。
    [*]游戏一开始代入感很强，很想电影的开场，让人很好奇接下去是什么，但游戏正片开始则让我有点失望，目前体验仅是躲猫猫生存收集物品钥匙。图一开始不是很大，就豪宅几层楼，后面应该会解开更多地点。
    [*]人物走动速度真的十分的慢，如果不用奔跑的话基本是蜗牛的速度。虽然游戏要主角潜行，但速度让节奏变得非常缓慢。
    [*]搜东西拉抽屉开箱子的手感比较差劲，配合慢节奏的移动速度又似乎后会让人抓狂。
    [*]变态老头的设定一开始还是很恐怖压抑的，但被老头发现后追逐过几场后立刻觉得游戏索然无味，恐怖度大大下降，[strike] 甚至到后面觉得老头还挺可爱的[/strike]。
[/list]

游戏本身潜力还是蛮大的，但鉴于目前是抢先体验阶段，相信后期会更新很多。我个人还是先打个不推荐吧。

39078980.review:
This negative is given for the early access build, so take that in mind when reading this. It's not 'bad', it's just that I can't currently recommend this and steam won't let me give a neutral review.

*The Good*
I'm honestly extremely excited to see where they take this, Clocktower/Haunting Grounds/Alien Isolation type horror games where there's a focus on a few memorable stalkers that you try and creep around. The game's graphics are solid for what they need to be (baring mouth animations) and very thematic.

 It's honestly pretty tense even in it's current state to creep around the mansion, and the fact that the stalkers aren't massively rubberbanded to you like some of the other games mentioned means that you can get a good feeling when you managed to slip past them. 

Also just having developers focus on stealth and avoidance in the current generation of gaming is worth some degree of praise from me.

*The Bad*
>It's understandably brief at present. 
>There's also a lot of genuienly annoying quirks with the systems in place; grabbing items is just annoying when getting them from cubbords or closets for instance since it'll generally lead to the game closing/shutting the cubbords instead of grabbing the item unless you're squared on it.
>It's also huge on stuttering and preformance issues.
> A lot of the facial animations are pretty questionable in general
>The voice acting is very hit and miss. To it's credit the stalkers are mostly hit.
>A lot of the gameplay tends to just be 'grab this item and take it over here'
>Stealth is very patchy and could use some more neuance. Maybe some light & dark mechanics as well?

*Suggestions/Ideas*
>Make all of the killers function differently would be a huge thing. <Spoilers>The girl in the attic approaches this with her sitting/not doing anything unless you grab something mechanics</spoilers> but it's not enough. The insect nun should cut you off with insects or use them to block doors temporarily or something whilst he's in a room. He gets a fantastic enterance and then pretty much acts like the first guy. I'm hoping that all of them have differing AI & mechanics to keep challenging the player; look at Haunting Grounds and what it did with it's stalkers. You can't really fight them, but all of them are still massively different from eachother in how they interact with you.
>Flesh out the stealth system some more, maybe with light and dark mechanics to make hiding more than just running to the nearest closet
>Expand upon the crafting in the game.
>Make more quests than go to X and do Y. 
>Stick to the current amount of rubberbanding, I'm actually really happy with it.
>Work on some better themes/OSTs for it. Legit playing some of the old Thief III themes in the background actually added a lot to my experience in this game.

I'll be carefully following this though and I'm very excited for where you guys will take it. I'd encourage people to support this game even if you aren't buying it presently just for what the developers are attempting to do here.

38892454.review:
If you enjoyed the tense, 'run-and-hide' thriller-esque atmosphere of classic games such as Clock Tower, Rule of Rose or Haunting Ground, I highly recommend you give this game a try.

It takes a little bit of time to get into the meat of the gameplay, but you'll quickly become an expert at hurling cups at your pursuers and diving into the nearest cover. The puzzles are very well placed and varied. As for the story, it's really quite immersive and haunting.

This is probably a minor detail, but the only thing that seemed off to me was the conversational pacing in the cutscenes. Feels like every sentence is blurted out and rushed so that the next line can immediately be spoken by the other characters. As for the voice acting, it's acceptable. It's interesting, because some may say that the voice acting needs work, but "old style" video games like these didn't feature that great of voice acting either. So it has the voiceovers going for it, yet also against it. It's hard to explain, but to me it's like this game is trying to seem like it was created back in the PS2 classic era of video games, but features the modern enhancements of widescreen displays and higher visual fidelity achievable today.

Overall, Remothered has hit atmosphere and story on the nail. I can't wait for the full story to be unlocked soon! I just wish there wasn't a planned trilogy announced this early, because now I know this first game will feature a cliffhanger of sorts, which I'm not a fan of because it leaves everyone waiting too long for the next installment.

You can't even tell it's early access!!!! ....except when the game abruptly ends on a cliffhanger.

Anyway, it's a great investment. You'll get maybe half a game here, but it's worth it. You definitely get that Clock Tower survival horror feeling - being trapped in a spooky location and stalked by some seriously creepy enemies. I was *truly* afraid playing this game, I screamed out loud several times, not from some jump scare but because I got spotted and had to run my ass off to avoid getting impaled by a psychopath.

The sound design is ridiculously good and goes a long way to making the game truly scary.

The enemies are weirdly sensitive to noise.... if you stop movnig in crouch they'll hone in on you, and if you run they'll find you in seconds. I guess it makes sense but you're in a three story mansion during a thunderstorm so it might be a bit TOO sensitive to be realistic. But it forces you to slowly creep around corners to make sure you're not gonna run into the baddies, which is tense and cinematic as hell.

La verdad es que técnicamente no es un portento, aunque hay que tener en cuenta que su versión final puede mejorar considerablemente algo más. Las animaciones son algo robóticas y las expresiones faciales tampoco dicen mucho.
En cuanto a la ambientación da bastante mal rollo, transmite ese agobio del personaje cuando intentamos evitar que nos vean o pillen. La IA del antagonista es bastante predecible y es fácil de evitar o escapar.
Los puntos de salvado escasean en la mansión, pero tampoco es que los necesites con bastante frecuencia, debido sobre todo a la torpe IA del antagonista. Haciendo comparativas, la IA del juego queda bastante lejos de lo que experimente en juegos como Alíen Isolation.
La historia está muy currada y según avanzas quieres saber más el secreto que encierra los ocupantes de la mansión. Por otro lado, el juego al estar en acceso anticipado no te deja acceder a los logros del mismo, lo cual tampoco es que resulte imprescindible para disfrutarlo.
Por lo tanto y para ir terminando, el juego en su base es interesante, su historia transmite empatía con el jugador. Aunque todavía le faltas bastantes cositas por pulir y sobre todo una IA algo más currada. También solucionar algún que otro bug que podría arruinar la partida casi llegando al final de este acceso anticipado, supongo que para la versión final ya estará solucionado.
En definitiva, si en su día te encanto aquellos juegos de PS2 llamados Clocktower o Haunting Ground no debes dejarlo escapar. Si en estas rebajas te sobran 10€ en el bolsillo es una buena inversión, te garantizada unas 4/5 horas de puro agobio jugable.

38804981.review:
A fair mix of Silent Hill, Silence of the Lambs, and Clock Tower / Haunting Grounds. I realize it is still in early access, and this review was written two months after its early access release, but on the off-chance that one of the folks working on this happens to see it, I'll leave some of its flaws in here—and will of course edit it later when it's fully released and I've played it again! Despite its flaws though, I thought it was a pretty good game overall for $10.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
• Wonderful atmosphere—the background music, the chase music, the diagetic music, and the scenery itself. This game's got it down fairly well.

• The characters are quite interesting. From our protagonist, Rosemary Reed, to our antagonists—those being [spoiler]Dr. Richard Felton[/spoiler], [spoiler]the Red Nun[/spoiler], and [spoiler]Celeste / Jennifer Felton[/spoiler]. The little collectibles tell things about these characters—mainly [spoiler]Dr. Felton[/spoiler]—that are very interesting as well!

• The story itself—as to be expected from something in thought for a few years—is great! 

• You can use sound to—sort of—determine where the killer is.

• You can defend yourself, in a way.

• You can heal at [spoiler]the mirrors with the metronomes in front of them[/spoiler].

• In a way, Rosemary Reed reminds me of Heather Mason from Silent Hill 3 and Clarice Starling from Silence of the Lambs.

[h1]Cons[/h1]
• It is very easy to escape your would-be killers. To be perfectly honest, I found myself looping around a few particular pillars and then crouching behind them to escape my stalkers. It worked almost every time, and when it didn't, I just found another place to loop around. I also found myself using a potted plant to hide behind and escape. It was funny, but that's not the point of this.

• The voice acting can definitely be improved upon. Also the character's lip-syncing with what they are saying—also in Ms. Reed's case, when she is breathing—is off a lot, if not all of the time.

• The cutscenes can definitely be improved upon as well, as there is a stark—harsh, even—difference between them and the game itself. Perhaps the dialogue should be slowed down a tad bit as well.

• 99.9% of the drawers, cabinets, and cupboards in the game are useless. I can only recall one or two times when I actually found something in one of them.

• It ends rather abruptly, as to be expected from a work in progress. Just adding this though.

• [spoiler]Don't be like me. Smash the mirrors with the bricks that you were supplied with. You'll know what I mean when you get there. It took me a couple of deaths to figure it out.[/spoiler]

• Save points are not [i]sparse[/i] per se, but if you're like me you'll find yourself going a while without saving.

• The character's choice of attire for this situation is plain stupid. At the least, she could have taken her heels off and shortened her skirt with one of the many sharp objects you find. But that's just me being me.


Again, overall this was a very good early access game for what it is—and if it is improved upon, it can only rise to further greatness.

E...bum! Um tapa na minha cara por este jogo! Subestimei esse título no começo, colocando defeito em tudo. Sou muito cético para jogos de terror. Dificilmente, algum me prende a atenção. Esse jogo me fez bocejar logo nos primeiros minutos. Achei 'interessantinho', mas o deixei de lado e tinha certeza que nunca mais iria jogá-lo. Numa hora dessas, abri o jogo, sem querer, e tentei jogar por mais uns 5 minutos. Poxa! Na verdade, fiquei quase a tarde toda. 

Primeiramente, interessou-me a combinação de jogo furtivo, ou seja, tentar esconder-se o tempo todo, com a estrutura dos 'Resident Evil's clássicos, isto é, buscar um item que encaixa, mesmo não tendo lógica, verossimilhança com a situação na vida real. Raramente, gosto de algum jogo que temos que jogar de maneira furtiva, mas a mecânica desse funciona muito bem! Lembrou-me 'Dead by Daylight', andando agachado atrás de objetos e tomando cuidado quando um som de alerta se intensifica indicando que o perigo se aproxima. No começo, achei péssima a precisão para pegar as armas de defesas, porém depois concordei que o jogo fica, de fato, muito mais tenso dessa maneira.

ESTOU ANSIOSO PELO JOGO FINAL!!!

38634897.review:
I purchased this game after reading some reviews referencing Clock Tower series. Just to be clear... Back in the days when the grass was greener I played Clock Tower 2 on PS1, which eventually became my gold standard for horror games; I got all possible endings, learned all dialogues by heart.. God.. Even tried to learn how to play that ending song.. 
So, when purchasing Remothered I was hoping for a similar experience with that eerie atmosphere of defenselessness and fear of the unknown.. Did I get it? - No. Don't get me wrong - it's a decent game and, imo, it's probably worth its 10 EUR if you're into horror games in general. 
But if you're expecting an experience similar to what you had with CT1-2,  sorry to disappoint you - it's not there. It feels more like an Outlast-type game than a Clock Tower one. Yes, there are some spooky moments and hide'n'seek stuff, but more frequently I felt I was playing a stealth game: "Ok. Now, I got 'the basement door key' - I probably have to go to the basement. Let's activate the alarm and hide behind the table. While [the bad guys] are searching for me in the wrong place, I'll pass by unnoticed and head further to my destination". 
Also, don't expect a finished story.. that's actually the most disappointing part to me, as the game ends when the things actually get interesting. 
Upvoting, only because it's a good beta. Purchase at your own risk.

P.S. (forgot to say what actually hooked me):
Rosemary Reed. She's certainly got a character, acting most of the time ballsy and (except for wearing high heels in a way too unfriendly environment) smart.
